label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, January 23, 1944
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing the tenants, atmosphere, and decor of the apartment house he and Morris purchased in Hawaii.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing the tenants, atmosphere, and decor of the apartment house he and Morris purchased in Hawaii.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
To
Mrs Sidney J. Legendre,
O.S.S. Detachment,
A.P.O NO. 887
Postermastern New York.
From 
Lt. S. Legendre, USNR
PO Box 166, Commandant
Navy No. 128
Fleet PO San Francisco
January 23, 1944
87
Dear Gertie,
Your letter of January 4, just arrived telling about you
wonderful weekend in the country ever NewYears eve with Lester and David
and it sounded heavenly. That big fat spaniel in the hall the size of a
heifer must have been wonderful and I could picutre the peace and loveliness
of the old inn, the fire, champagne and wonderful stories about Africa.
I am so glad you had a good time and hope that many more week ends will
come by for you like that one.
We have had a funny week end ourselves. Today being Sunday
Morris of course went to the office but he returned at two oclock because 
we had an appintment with the women who is to run our apartment house for
us. She works with the Hawaiian Trust Co. This co. makes a speciality
of managing apartment houses which takes the load off out shoulders and 
also avoids the worries and annoyances that we saw only to clearly would
be our lot should we try to manage the house ourselves. Today we went
around with her to see al the tennants and it was hysterical. Morris had
his best go to meeting manner and was running for mayor in a big way.
The first aprtment we went into was owned by a women of about forty five
who immediately lit into us and said that her apartment was filthy , she
wanted it done over, the walls repainted, new drapes and less noise in the
neighborhood. Morris smiled his sweetest smile bowed low when she was thru
and we went out. Our apartment manager said when we had closed the door
shall I start have that work done right away. "Hell no " Morris said
"do nothing, we dont want her in here. Do nothing." As we passed her
a artment latter she stuck her head out of the door again and said "and
I want my screens fixed." Morris replied "Madam I can promise you that
within a short time you will not have anything in this apartment to complain
about" which was very true. Many of the aprtments are occupied by defenc se
workers who are filthy. They come home in their greasy clothes sit down
in the chairs and lie on the beds so that grease is over everything. W
Are also going to try and get them out and secure better tennants but the
law out here does not let you put a person out of an apartment of house
if they are already occuping it. Unless you yourself are going to live 
there. As we evidently cannot live in all the aprtments at onxe time we
may run into a little trouble, but that is something that we will and see.
We have already arranged to have an landscape archestect come out on
Thursday to adivse us on the planting of vines, palm trees flowers to
make the place more attractive and a contract is being prepared with a
floor poslihsing co.to polish all the floors, wax the red concrete halls
and entrance. Morris os of course in his element and you can be sure is
dam good at it. Unfortunately the newspapers printed the fact that we
had purchased this apartment house on their frontpages and this has caused
an avalnche of calls as to whether we have an aprtment for rent. Captains
and commanders who did [illegible] before stop us now and say "
Good mor ing my boy, h[illegible] have an aprtment for rent
Sidney Legendre
